important_phrase: Wile domestic poultry demand remained subdued, poultry producers experienced relatively strong export sales to Asia, Mexico, and Eastern Europe
Labor markets weakened further and holiday-related hiring plans were restrained
For businesses that reported they were hiring, several indicated difficulty in recruiting workers because of increasing relocation costs resulting from having to sell an existing home
Credit conditions remained tight, and competition for deposits increased
Most contacts reported that holiday-related shipments of consumer goods were down significantly from last year
However, some markets, particularly in Florida, saw modest gains in sales over weak year-ago levels
In an attempt to stimulate sales, several retailers noted that they have expanded store hours, increased advertising, and plan deeper discounts
Most software and information technology services respondents see a slowdown currently or in the near future, while temp firms cite a marked falloff in business in November
Rising unemployment has improved labor supply, but it is still difficult to fill positions for engineers, programmers, healthcare lab personnel, and IT-professionals
A few contacts note that clients are delaying deals until there is less market uncertainty or are slowing down payments, thus elongating the sales cycle
In Connecticut, sales volume is reportedly very low and financing limited
Inventory levels continue to be tightly managed
Milk, hog, and cattle prices moved lower, and there were concerns about bankruptcies in the livestock industry
Credit conditions remained tight, but improved in some markets
Fuel surcharges also continued to be of concern as the price of diesel fuel remained elevated
Credit conditions in the District continued to be tight, but improved in some markets
Most contacts reported little impact of tighter business credit on their own operations
Residential building continued its steady decline
Contacts expressed concern that the holiday shopping season would be weak
Wrkforce levels held steady, and no hiring is expected in the near future
Residential construction remains very weak, with no improvement expected during 2009
Credit quality of incoming applicants was characterized as stable to slightly down
Capacity utilization was at or below normal levels
Several firms attributed the slowdown, in part, to difficulties in financing projects
Looking forward, respondents expect a relatively weak holiday shopping season
Growing conditions in much of the District remained generally favorable
Almost all respondents voiced concern about the near-term outlook with expectations of improvement ranging from about four to twelve months away
The main exception was accounting firms which continued to add staff but at a slower pace
Contacts foresee a weak, highly-uncertain economy and continue to evaluate potential borrowers with the same high level of scrutiny as reported in the last survey
Demand for consumer products was moderately weaker with some low-end electronics seeing some strength
Respondents said apartment demand remains relatively solid and rental growth remains positive but slower
Discount stores are not slowing as much as department stores
Farm loan demand strengthened with rising input costs, and the availability of funds for operating loans fell modestly
Residential real estate activity continued on a downward trend and the energy sector slowed moderately, while agricultural conditions were largely unchanged
Price pressures eased further in October and November, and wage pressures were limited due to softer labor markets
Bankers reported lower loan demand, tighter credit standards, and weaker loan quality since the last survey
Manufacturing activity declined sharply after slowing in the late summer months
Most real estate contacts expected a decrease in revenue growth for 2009 due to slower sales and reduced credit access
Stre inventories remained fairly flat, however, as the recent weak sales were largely expected
Agricultural conditions improved since the last report
Overall wage increases were modest, while a number of product prices decreased
Wge increases were modest
) indicated significantly decreased activity in Minnesota, but increased activity in the Dakotas
Commercial real estate slowed
Consumer spending decreased
Districts reported mixed results in agriculture
Agricultural conditions were mixed with a relatively good harvest but concerns about profitability
Wge pressures were largely subdued
Chicago reported that FDCactions and Federal Reserve lending had improved liquidity and slowed deposit outflows
A few sectors saw increased activity
Residential real estate continued at a slow pace nationwide
Tourism activity was relatively slow
Finally, bankers report widespread weakening in loan demand across all segments, substantial tightening in credit standards, and higher delinquency rates on all types of loans
For all loan categories, respondents indicate widespread tightening of credit standards
A growing proportion of firms--both manufacturers and other firms--report tightening credit conditions over the past three months
Leasing activity has slowed markedly, and many tenants are requesting short-term renewals, with landlords generally willing to oblige
Average ticket prices have been relatively steady
Motor vehicle dealers reported very slow sales
Reports on input costs and output prices reveal a general decline since the previous Beige Book
Looking ahead, bankers generally expect, at best, slow expansion in lending in 2009
Among firms polled in November, a little more than one-third expect new orders and shipments to decline during the next six months, and a little less than one-third expect increases
Residential real estate activity in the Third District has softened in recent weeks

Nearly all the auto dealers in the region surveyed in November reported a very slow pace of sales, well below the rate of a year ago, although a few noted a slight improvement from the September and October sales rate
Cooler-than-normal temperatures coupled with above average rainfall helped replenish soil moisture in much of the District, but delayed field work in some regions
Other contacts noted that finished goods prices declined, which they attributed to slower business and weaker demand for their products
" In general, wages remained unchanged across the District

" Changes in credit standards were mixed, with some lenders reporting a slight tightening of loan-to-value ratios and stricter credit policies, while others indicated no revisions over the last six weeks
Other contacts noted that finished goods prices declined, which they attributed to slower business and weaker demand for their products
Commercial real estate contacts across the District generally noted slower leasing activity since our last report
Retail sales contracted since our last report, as big-ticket sales fell sharply and shopper traffic declined
Among oil extractors, weaker demand and lower output prices have reduced the viability of higher cost expansion projects, causing many to be delayed or shelved
Manufacturing activity slowed further
Upward pressures on prices moderated during the survey period
District banking contacts reported that lending activity and credit conditions weakened significantly during the survey period
District manufacturing activity slowed further during the survey period of mid-October through late November
Demand for commercial real estate declined, with increases in office and industrial vacancy rates reported for various cities
Providers of health-care services reported slower activity and concerns over their ability to issue debt to fund needed capital spending
Most District states were ahead of normal with winter wheat planting, but crop growth was slightly behind normal in most states
Since our last report, manufacturing experienced significant declines, but the services sector improved slightly
Demand for all types of residential mortgage loans was moderately weaker, while credit standards for these loans tightened somewhat
A firm in the transportation services sector announced expansion and new hiring plans
Commercial real estate was mixed
Essential items were strong sellers, while high-end furniture, apparel, and gift items sales slowed
